chapterTitle: Financial Leverage and Capital Structure Policy

columns.text: In this problem, we will deal with multiple solutions regarding the valuation of a company using the different parameters provided in the questions.
When financing a purchase, a firm can choose to either use equity, debt, or a mixture of both. This all depends on their capital structure which can be defined by their debt-equity ratio.

In order to get the total earnings, we can simply take the annual earnings of $\$14,125,000$ and multiply it to one minus the tax rate of $0.23$. This will give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Total earnings}&=\$14,125,000\times (1-0.23)\\[15 pt]
&=\$10,876,250
\end{aligned}$$

The total earnings after tax is $\$10,876,250$.

We can then substitute the total earnings, the cost of capital which is given as $0.102$ and the total cost of $\$85,000,000$ to the formula in Step 3 to get the net present value of the company.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Net present value}&=\dfrac{\$10,876,250}{0.102}-\$85,000,000\\[15 pt]
&=\$21,629,901.96
\end{aligned}$$

The net present value of this project is $\$21,629,901.96$

**b.)** In order to construct the market value balance sheet, we need to identify first the new equity value of the company after the purchase. This can be solved using this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New equity value}&=\text{Equity value before purchase}+\text{Net present value}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Take note that the equity value before the purchase is $\$302,400,000$. Substituting this to the formula, we will get:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{New equity value}&=\$302,400,000+\$21,629,901.96\\[15 pt]
&=\$324,029,901.96
\end{aligned}$$

The new equity value of the company is $\$324,029,901.96$

Since all of the funds used are from equity, then we will have a market value balance sheet that looks like this:

|Assets |$324,029,901.96 | 
|--|--| 
|Debt |-$0.00 | 
| Equity| $324,029,901.96|

Since we now have the total assets of the company, we can solve for the new price per share of the stock by dividing it to the number of outstanding shares which is $8,000,000$

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price per share}&=\dfrac{\$324,029,901.96}{8,000,000}\\[15 pt]
&=\$40.504
\end{aligned}$$

The new price per share is $\$40.504$

From this new stock, we can solve for the number of shares needed to fund the purchase. To do this, we will use this formula:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of shares needed}&=\dfrac{\text{Cost}}{\text{Price per share}}\\[15 pt]
&=\dfrac{\$85,000,000}{\$40.504}\\[15 pt]
&=2,098,558.167
\end{aligned}$$


He needs to issue $2,098,558.167$ shares in order to finance the purchase.

**c.)** Once the equity is issued and the purchase has not yet been made, the number of outstanding shares will increase. The original number of outstanding shares will increase by the number of shares needed to fund the purchase. This will give us:

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Number of outstanding shares}&=8,000,000+2,098,558.167\\[15 pt]
&=10,098,558.17
\end{aligned}$$

From this, we can take the value of the firm's assets in Step 7 and divide it by the number of outstanding shares to get the price per share of the firm's stock.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Price per share}&=\dfrac{\$324,029,901.96}{10,098,558.17}\\[15 pt]
&=\$32.087
\end{aligned}$$

The current price per share is $\$32.087$

The current asset value of the company will also increase by the cost of the purchase which is $\$85,000,000$ since this has not yet been used to pay for the purchase. The new balance sheet will then be:

|Assets |$409,029,901.96 | 
|--|--| 
|Debt |-$0.00 | 
| Equity| $409,029,901.96|

**d.)** After the purchase has been made we can take the after tax earnings in Step 4 and divide it by the cost of capital to get the present value of the project.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Present value}&=\dfrac{\$10,876,250}{0.102}\\[15 pt]
&=\$106,629,902
\end{aligned}$$

The present value of the earnings from this purchase is $\$106,629,902$

We can then add the present value to the Equity value in Step 7 to get the current equity value.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Equity value}&=\$324,029,901.96+106,629,902\\[15 pt]
&=\$430,659,803.96
\end{aligned}$$

This will give us a balance sheet of:
|Assets |$430,659,803.96 | 
|--|--| 
|Debt |-$0.00 | 
| Equity| $430,659,803.96|
As we can see from all of the balance sheets, only the equity is included since it is assumed at the very start of this problem that all finances come from equity.
